Ask HN: How much is reasonable to charge for rescuing a web app?
text:
Hi fellow freelancers at hn,

Over the last years, I have been commonly found with potential customers in situations where their production app is either down or its main feature is not working (my last work involved a project where previous dev deleted all prod infrastructure).

I have helped them to get their production app back to a working state, which usually takes less than 10h, I just did that again and it took me only 2 hours (causing a tiny bill)! I'm feeling that these small bills aren't worth it for the emergency mindset.

I'm aware that billing by value instead of by time is a common advice but it isn't clear to me on how much I could actually charge for this kind of task. Is this something we can put a price tag before having enough context?

P.S. The reason I usually charge by time is because I have got many estimations wrong, there was a time where I worked on a so-complex project where getting it back on track took many exhausting days.

I'll appreciate any advice.

Show HN: Embra – A fast, Chat-GPT like assistant for your Mac. App integrated
text:
Hey HN!

We're building Embra, an always-one-second away GPT assistant that integrates into your OS, apps, and workflows.

Everyone is talking about the "context problem" as it relates to GPT, in that the answers you get out are only as good as the information you put in. And, well, a lot of users don't want to type in a bunch of text.

With Embra, you can pick and choose which context to feed the AI within the interface itself. And that context can be anywhere on your computer -- text in a PDF document, any tabs within Chrome, etc.

One of the primary use cases is improved coding, debugging, and software workflows. We especially want to gather feedback in this direction, as engineers engage in Q&A workflows and code creation 15+ times a day. Really awesome. :)

Just launching our closed beta signup page today, and rolling out first invites to broader community.

https://embra.app/

And the twitter launch thread: https://twitter.com/zachtratar/status/1623015294569713665

We're also looking for the following feedback:

1) What do you think about OS-level integration vs VSCode extension? Both have filesystem access, but do you perceive them differently security or capability wise? 2) What do you use ChatGPT for today primarily, and would desktop access improve those workflows meaningfully? 3) What context would you like to pull into the AI, as an engineer?

Thanks! And feel free to poke at the idea. We've been around the block and welcome the classic, ruthless HN constructive criticism.

Ask HN: Is the mental health market ready to be disrupted?
text:
I am sure that Clayton Christensen would respond "NO", since according to Clay a market can only be disrupted once it's overserved.

And the mental health market is anything but overserved. A cottage industry, questionable practitioners, high level of customer dissatisfaction, and exorbitant pricing.

There are legal barrier to entry, but that has never dissuaded innovators from rattling the cage.

What will be the Napster for therapy?
